subhead: Philippe, who served as the first of Macron's seven prime ministers, called for an early presidential election after the adoption of the 2026 budget.

headline: France's left more fragmented than ever after Lecornu's resignation
subhead: The Socialists are still looking to present themselves as a fallback option for governing the country, while the radical left La France Insoumise called again for President Emmanuel Macron's departure.

headline: First day of Hamas-Israel talks in Egypt ends on 'positive' note, mediators say
subhead: The first day of indirect talks between Hamas and Israel concluded in Cairo on Monday 'amid a positive atmosphere,' with US President Donald Trump saying Hamas is agreeing 'to things that are very important.'

headline: Trump's ineffective campaign to secure the Nobel Peace Prize
subhead: The American president's aggressive tactics have taken Norwegian experts by surprise. Yet in Oslo, the committee responsible for awarding the prize remains unfazed by attempts at influence, according to its secretary.

headline: Israeli kibbutzim ravaged by October 7 attacks rebuild while honoring the past
subhead: Be'eri, Kfar Aza and Nir Oz were the communities hit the hardest by the attack carried out by Hamas two years ago. Since then, each has tried to reinvent itself, in its own way and at its own pace.

subhead: While France captivates with its culture and lifestyle, the French, frequently caricatured as arrogant and impolite, often have a poor reputation. This ambivalence raises questions about the roots of anti-French sentiment abroad.

headline: Sweden's new list of 'cultural values' sparks controversy
subhead: 'Pippi Longstocking,' Ikea, Bergman: In early September, Sweden's conservative government unveiled a list aimed at defining a 'common frame of reference' to promote the integration of foreigners. The opposition has condemned the project's nostalgic vision.

headline: Sébastien Lecornu's full speech after resigning
subhead: After submitting his resignation to Emmanuel Macron, Sébastien Lecornu, who served for 27 days as prime minister, delivered a speech on Monday morning.
